title-group.article-title: A Generalizable Speech Emotion Recognition Model Reveals Depression and Remission

abstract.p: Objective: Affective disorders are associated with atypical voice patterns; however, automated voice analyses suffer from small sample sizes and untested generalizability on external data. We investigated a generalizable approach to aid clinical evaluation of depression and remission from voice using transfer learning: we train machine learning models on easily accessible non-clinical datasets and test them on novel clinical data in a different language. Methods: A Mixture-of-Experts machine learning model was trained to infer happy/sad emotional state using three publicly available emotional speech corpora in German and US English. We examined the model's predictive ability to classify the presence of depression on Danish speaking healthy controls (N = 42), patients with first-episode major depressive disorder (MDD) (N = 40), and the subset of the same patients who entered remission (N = 25) based on recorded clinical interviews. The model was evaluated on raw, de-noised, and speaker-diarized data. Results: The model showed separation between healthy controls and depressed patients at the first visit, obtaining an AUC of 0.71. Further, speech from patients in remission was indistinguishable from that of the control group. Model predictions were stable throughout the interview, suggesting that 20-30 seconds of speech might be enough to accurately screen a patient. Background noise (but not speaker diarization) heavily impacted predictions. Conclusion: A generalizable speech emotion recognition model can effectively reveal changes in speaker depressive states before and after remission in patients with MDD. Data collection settings and da-ta cleaning are crucial when considering automated voice analysis for clinical purposes.

fn.p: 1. Table 1 has been remade to include other clinical variables available to us (years of education, and various tests of cognitive function). Further, the table now includes more statistics for the variables such as mean, standard deviation, median, min, max for numeric variables and raw counts and percentages for categorical variables. 2. More background information on participants in the study has been added such as HamD-17 cutoff, how controls were recruited, and information on comorbidity. 3. The abstract has been slightly reworded: a. Objective now more clearly defines what we mean with generalizability and introduces transfer learning. b. Methods specifies the language of the training data sets and makes it clear that the group in remission is a subset of the depressed group. c. References to treatment effect have been removed or reformulated to be remission effect. 5. Several new paragraphs have been added in the discussion. These relate to: a. More discussion on the advantages/disadvantages of our type of data collection. b. A discussion of the limitations of doing binary prediction as compared to multi-diagnosis and what this implies for clinical use cases of the current state of the model. 6. A new figure in the supplementary materials showing the difference in Hamilton scores as a function of the difference in P(Happy) for depressed patients. 7. Added information on the employment status of Yan-Ping Zhang, Detlef Wolf, and Konstantinos Sechidis to the COI statement 8.
